1074377268284276737.text:
A demonstration of the importance of punctuation, by my mother:

Boris said, "Theresa may resign".
"Boris", said Theresa, "may resign".
Boris said, "Theresa May: Resign!"
"Boris," said Theresa May: "Resign".

1037856808109527040.text: Systems that have high safety and no liveness sometimes will halt mid-execution to prevent crashes from happening, and systems that have liveness but no safety may continue to operate, even if they are producing incorrect or inaccurate results. 5/5

1037856723170668544.text: Attaining both safety and liveness happens only when everyone gets to their end location without getting in a car crash. 4/5

1037856524004216833.text: However, if everyone is sitting idle, nobody will get to their destination. Of course, getting to your destination is also an important aspect of a road system, and so it can be considered the liveness property of the system. 3/5

1037856373323845632.text: Imagine the US road system a multiprocess program with each car its own process. One can achieve safety trivially by having all cars remain idle in their garages. Obviously, no one will get into an accident if no one is driving, so of course, your system will achieve safety. 2/5

1037856321335422977.text: To understand safety and liveness better: think of it like a road system. Safety is the guarantee that something bad (an accident) will not happen, and liveness is the guarantee that something good will happen (everyone reaches their destination). 1/5

1035661740690690049.text: Nakamoto's longest-chain consensus is novel and secure and an innovative feature of Bitcoin. Proof of Work, on the other hand, stems from the early 1980s, was developed by researcher Cynthia Dwork, and had been previously explored for usage in email spam prevention.

1035660360139689985.text: Likewise, it's not Proof of Stake consensus. It's PBFT consensus or Tendermint consensus or some other consensus mechanism that uses Stake to determine voting power as a Sybil resistance mechanism.

1035659433739603968.text: Proof of Work is a Sybil control mechanism NOT a consensus mechanism. It's Nakamoto consensus, not PoW consensus!

1024085470307700737.text: Transaction fee manipulation kills decentralization. Decentralization requires both decentralized ownership and decentralized usership. But, when manipulated, inordinate gas costs and tx fees make usership impossible for millions who simply cannot afford to use the blockchain.

1022996652557123584.text: While a fragmented cryptocurrency space sounds precarious, the idea gives me comfort. Having one coin is anticompetitive. If you believe competition is innovation's friend, then, in a winner-take-all market, the winning coin would ossify absent competitor-fueled improvement.

1022996651894439936.text: I used to think that cryptocurrency was a winner-take-all market. The network effects that the "best" currency would accrue would prevent other currencies from succeeding. Now, I foresee multiple cryptocurrencies succeeding at the same time.

1022610350506557441.text: Really enjoyed @glenweyl's talk at @BloombergBeta. Particularly enjoyed Radical Market's ability to present controversial political ideals in a non partisan manner; this book is neither left nor right and will make you question the things that modern societies take for granted.

1022226789215526912.text: Unfortunately, in order for game theory to be truly predictive of emergent behavior in a blockchain, incentives must be designed with respect to potentially infinitely many nodes and infinitely many rounds (not 2 players and one round). That is hard, and remains largely unsolved.

1022225730187362304.text: Blockchain researchers are excited by game theory because it provides an extremely simple adversarial environment in which to tweak incentive design. The simplicity usually comes from modelling incentives as a two-player, single-round game.
